title: U.S. Real Estate Market Will Likely Stay the Course Despite Impeachment Inquiry
text:
Despite the political uncertainty created by the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, the fallout is unlikely to reverberate throughout the nation’s real estate market, experts said Wednesday.



A formal impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump was announced Tuesday evening over allegations that he used his presidency to pressure Ukraine into investigating Joe Biden. It marks the first move in a comprehensive political process that has only been held three other times in U.S. history.



More: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Last Home Goes up For Auction

“The real estate market is dependent on factors that have to do with the economy, consumer confidence and the stock market,” Donna Olshan, president of Olshan Realty, who closely tracks the luxury market in her weekly reports on New York City’s high-end real estate. “If any one of those things goes down for a sustained period, it will affect us, but right now stocks are up. Wall Street is finding this is a non-event.”



At market close on Wednesday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 162.94 points.



“The stock market is able to shake off the daily Trump machinations,” Ms. Olshan said. “People don't get as panicked.”



The latest news is just the most recent in a presidency that has been rife with tension and negative headlines.



“There’s been a lot over the last year,” said Jonathan Miller, chief executive of real estate appraisal firm Miller Samuel and author of several Douglas Elliman market reports focusing on cities and towns around the U.S.



“It’s a continuing narrative of uncertainty,” Mr. Miller said, and “right now there's nothing to suggest [impeachment] is providing additional uncertainty.” Nor will it be shocking people into changing their behavior, he said.



The proceedings are unlikely to change how the majority of people across the U.S. approach their real estate acquisitions or sales, according to Redfin lead economist Taylor Marr.



“People are going to move based on life changes: having kids, marriages, retiring. Those are the drivers,” Mr. Marr told Mansion Global. “Most evidence that we can look at for how things like this have an effect on the market show it's usually pretty small, if any.”



From Penta: Australian Billionaire Andrew Forrest Aims to End Plastic Pollution

Across the pond, the U.K.’s still-undecided exit from the European Union demonstrates that substantial political uncertainty and upheaval can have a drastic effect on real estate markets, but in this case, the disruption is far from substantial enough to have the same implications, experts say.



“Something like Brexit is a structural shift, an economic wedge being driven between the U.K. and Europe,” said Paul Habibi, continuing lecturer of finance and real estate at UCLA Anderson Graduate School of Management. But “the removal of a president doesn't mean a structural shift,” and is more simply just part of the cyclical ebbs and flows of the market, he said.



“My eye is more on the potential for a Chinese trade war,” he said, referring to ongoing economic conflict between the U.S. and China. “Some of these things are bigger potential issues than the impeachment inquiry.”



If House members determine there is enough evidence against Mr. Trump following the inquiry, the body must vote on articles of impeachment, which is a set of charges against the president.



Only two presidents have been impeached in U.S. history, President Andrew Johnson in 1868 and President Bill Clinton in 1998. President Richard Nixon resigned in 1974 following the initiation of the impeachment process but before actual impeachment.



No president has been removed from office as a result of the impeachment proceedings, and it’s highly unlikely that the majority Republican Senate would vote to remove Mr. Trump if it were to advance to that chamber.



Even in the event that he does get removed from office, there still won’t be a drastic effect on the real estate market, Mr. Habibi said, as Vice President Mike Pence would take over and there would be no change in policy.



In regards to the next step to Tuesday’s announced proceedings, six House committees are now expected to compile evidence on impeachable offenses by President Trump and send their cases against him to the Judiciary Committee.
